topics: What kind of advertising do you like?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and Suggestions

What kind of advertising catches your interest? (Visual effects, humor, storytelling, usage of celebrities, etc.)

Why do you like the advertising? (Captivates attention, makes you laugh, engages emotionally, interesting play of words, etc.)

Where do you often see your favourite kind of advertising? (TV, social media, billboard, radio, newspapers, etc.)

Who features prominently in your favourite advertisements? (Celebrities, cartoon characters, ordinary people, animals, etc.)

Section 2: Sample Answers

I am a massive fan of humorous advertising, especially those that play on popular culture and puns. They instantly captivate my attention and make the message more memorable. I find that these types of advertising are most prevalent on TV and social media platforms. Invariably, renowned celebrities or even fictional characters are commonly featured in these advertisements, which enhances my interest even more.

Personally, I find storytelling advertising extremely appealing. These types of advertisements evoke an emotional connection which makes the brand more relatable. Whether itâ€™s a heartwarming story or a thrilling narrative, it helps in retaining the brand in my memory. I often come across such types of advertising in online videos and sometimes on billboards. Invariably, these advertisements depict ordinary people navigating through their lives which adds to their relatability.

I have a fondness for advertisements that incorporate creative visual effects and animations. These types of advertising are a treat to the eyes and often deliver the brand's message in artistic and innovative ways. I frequently see such advertisements on digital platforms and cinema commercials. The characters featuring in these ads can range from animated characters to real-life models, adding an extra element of interest.

topics: Do you like advertisements?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions for the Topic "Do you like advertisements?"

What types of advertisements do you find most appealing?

Suggestions: humor-based ads, emotional narrative, informational ads, minimalist ads

Why do you like or dislike advertisements?

Suggestions: interruption, persuasive, informative, entertaining

When do you pay most attention to advertisements?

Suggestions: while watching television, browsing internet, reading magazines

How do advertisements affect your purchasing decisions?

Suggestions: influence, persuasion, brand awareness, promotions

Examples of Responses to the Question "Do you like advertisements?"

Generally, I appreciate what ads bring to the table. I particularly enjoy humor-based ads as they tickle my fancy while also informing me about a product or service. However, I dislike ads that disrupt my favorite shows or browsing experience without adding value.

Why do I like advertisements? When done right, they can be informative and entertaining. On top of that, they add variety to the programming of television and radio. Still, admittedly, when ads are overly repetitive or misleading, they do irk me.

How do advertisements affect my purchases? It's undeniable that ads can sometimes persuade me to try out new things or remind me of products I've forgotten. However, I tend to rely more heavily on customer reviews and personal research when making purchase decisions.

topics: Do you see a lot of advertising on trains or other transport?
solutions:
WH-questions and suggestions for answering:

What types of advertisements are commonly seen in trains? - mention the product categories, brand names, digital or printed format, etc.

Where are these advertisements located within train or other transport? - describe the physical locations on the transport where ads are placed.

Who are the target audiences for these advertisements? - identify the main demographics and characteristics expected to see these ads.

Why do companies choose to advertise on trains and other forms of transport? - possible advantages like high visibility, captive audience, etc.

How effective do you think these advertisements are? - give personal opinions and observations on the attention and reactions they catch from passengers.

Examples of answering this question:

What types of advertisements are commonly seen in trains? From my observations, I've seen a mix of different types of advertising on trains. These range from movies and TV shows to consumer goods, banks, and even healthcare services. Some are on printed banners while others are displayed on digital screens present inside the train cars.

Where are these advertisements located within train or other transport? Advertisements on the train are typically placed where they can easily catch passengers' attention. This often includes spaces like the overhead compartments, back of the seats, on the doors, and even on the exterior of the train. Digitally however, they're displayed on screens that are mounted on the ceilings or walls of the train cars.

Who are the target audiences for these advertisements? The target audience for these advertisements are generally daily commuters. This covers a broad demographic including students, working professionals, and seniors. Certain ads might target specific groups, like ads for daycare services targeting parents, or those for online learning platforms targeting students.

topics: Is there an advertisement that made an impression on you when you were a child?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and suggestions in phrases and words

Which are some advertisements that you remember from childhood? (Favorite food product, toy, cartoon, movie, outing spot etc.)

What about these advertisements stood out to you? (Characters, jingle/soundtrack, humor, emotion, animation etc.)

When did you see these advertisements? (Early mornings, after school, weekends, during a particular TV show etc.)

Why did these advertisements make an impression on you? (Reminder of good times, evoked strong feelings, shared experiences with friends/family etc.)

How do these advertisements affect your choices or preferences today? (Favorite food, preferred brand, interest in a hobby/activity etc.)

Section 2: 3 Examples answered the question

I remember seeing the advertisement for the Lego building blocks when I was a child. It aired during my favorite Saturday morning cartoon show. The ad was full of dazzling colors and interesting characters, which instantly sparked my creativity and interest in building things. Even today, I have a soft spot for Lego and enjoy assembling it with my kids.

One advertisement that left a deep impression on me as a child was a cereal commercial. The ad had catchy jingle, which I found myself often humming. The funny cartoon character in the ad was endearing, and made breakfast seem like the most exciting meal of the day. As an adult, I always associate breakfast cereals with fun and energy, which I try to incorporate in my daily routine.

As a kid, the Barbecue Chips commercial used to air late afternoons when I came home from school. The ad was full of fun, laughter, and irresistible deliciousness. It made me associate the chips with happiness and togetherness, which is probably why it's my go-to snack even today during watching a movie or enjoying a games night with friends.

topics: Do you think childhood is boring or adulthood is boring?
solutions:
Childhood or Adulthood: Which is Boring?

WH-Questions and Suggestions:

Who is more likely to feel bored - a child or an adult? Words and phrases: curiosity, capacity for wonder, responsibilities, job striking

What are the activities that a child and an adult can do? Words and phrases: games, imagination, work, socializing

When do children and adults experience the most boredom? Words and phrases: school hours, working hours, weekends, holidays

Where do children and adults experience boredom? Words and phrases: home, school, workplace, social events

Why do children and adults feel boredom? Words and phrases: lack of novelty, repetitive tasks, insufficient mental stimulation

Examples of Answers:

Adults are generally more likely to feel bored than children. Children, who naturally have a greater capacity for wonder and curiosity, are usually busy exploring the world around them. Meanwhile, adult responsibilities like maintaining a job can be mundane and monotonous, leading to more periods of boredom.

Independence can largely affect the boredom level. Children's activities are usually restricted to the safe boundaries set by adults, limiting their experiences and thus potentially leading to boredom. On the other hand, adults have more freedom to seek out novel experiences but may be limited by time, responsibilities, or simple lack of interest.

The feeling of boredom is not exclusive to a specific location for both children and adults. A child might feel bored in school due to repetitive lessons, just like an adult in a mundane work meeting. At home, both might experience boredom if they lack stimulating activities. However, this can be mitigated if they can engage in something they find interesting or challenging.

topics: What do you do when you feel bored?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggested Phrases or Words

What do you like to do in your spare time? E.g., reading, painting, cooking, exercising, etc.

Where can you explore new places? E.g., nearby parks, museums, cafes, neighbourhoods, etc.

Who can you get in touch with? E.g., old friends, cousins, mentors, etc.

Why not start a hobby you've always wanted to try? E.g., playing an instrument, learning a new language, gardening, etc.

How about improving your skills? E.g., professional skills, culinary skills, artistic skills, etc.

Examples Answering the WH-Questions

Whenever I feel bored, I often engage in what I like to do in my spare time, which is reading. I have a collection of books at home, ranging from fiction genres to self-improvement ones. It always helps me to kill time and acquire new knowledge.

If I want to change the atmosphere a bit, I explore where I can experience something new. Nearby parks are ideal for a short trekking or a picnic. Sometimes, I visit museums or cafes, which not only offers a change of scenery but also enriches my cultural understanding.

I also try to connect with who I haven't talked to for a while. This could be my old friends, cousins, or mentors. It's always great to rekindle old relationships and catch up on what's going on in each other's lives.

topics: When would you feel bored?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggested Phrases or Words

Where do you usually feel the most bored?

Suggested phrases and words: office, home, school, in traffic, at social events

When do you typically find yourself feeling bored?

Suggested phrases and words: during meetings, in classes, on days off, while studying, during conversations

What activities or situations usually bore you?

Suggested phrases and words: repetitive tasks, monotonous work, endless meetings, lack of stimulating discussions, lack of challenge

Who you feel the most bored with?

Suggested phrases and words: certain friends, colleagues, family members, acquaintances

Why do you feel bored in these situations?

Suggested phrases and words: lack of interest, lack of engagement, lack of novelty, not challenging enough, feeling of repetition

Examples Answering the Question

I usually feel most bored at work, especially during long, drawn-out meetings that don't pertain to my specific role within the company. I am the kind of person who thrives on actively participating and contributing to conversations, and when I can't do this, I quickly lose interest.

There are times when I find myself feeling bored at school, particularly during classes that involve a lot of theoretical and less practical work. Whenever the subject matter is not directly related to my field of interest or doesn't challenge me intellectually, I tend to lose focus and interest.

On my days off, I sometimes feel bored, especially when I haven't made any specific plans. I thrive on a healthy mix of relaxation and engagement, and if there's too much of one without the other (for example, too much idle time without any stimulating activity), I start to feel restless and bored.

topics: Do you often feel bored?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and Suggestions

Why do you feel bored? - Lack of motivation, unchallenging tasks, repetitive routine

When do you often feel bored? -Specific times of day, during certain activities, particular situations

What activities make you feel bored? - Office work, household chores, long drives

Who are you with when you feel bored? - Alone, with colleagues, with family

Where do you often feel bored? - Workplace, home, social events

Section 2: Example Answers

I often feel bored when I am at work. The tasks assigned to me are repetitive and I can finish them without much thought, leaving me with hours to spend doing nothing. My productivity decreases and I end up feeling restless and unfulfilled.

I usually feel boredom striking me during the early afternoon. I find myself feeling less energetic which impacts my ability to concentrate on my tasks. I typically feel the monotony when I am alone at home, spending consecutive hours without any social interaction.

Most often, I get extremely bored during long car rides or when I am stuck in heavy traffic. These moments of complete standstill are overwhelmingly dull. I am left unengaged with my surroundings and the lack of stimulating activities make the situation even more boring.

topics: Would you invite friends to your home?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions

Who are the friends you are planning to invite? Consider if they get along with each other, their interests and if they live nearby.

What kind of event or gathering do you want to host? This could include a dinner party, game night, movie marathon, etc.

When is a convenient time for you and your friends? Perhaps ask them for their preferred dates or days of the week.

Where in your home would the gathering be? Suggestions could be living room, backyard, dining room, etc.

Why do you want to invite them over? Celebrating a special occasion, simple get together, or just bonding time could be reasons.

Examples of responses:

Yes, I would invite my friends over to my home, specifically my friends from college as we have not met since graduation. I would love to host a dinner party next Saturday, as it is the best day for everyone. The gathering would take place in my backyard. The main reason I am inviting them is for us to catch up and reconnect after a long time.

I am planning to invite some of my friends over to a game night at my house. This includes my friends from the neighborhood who I know enjoy board games. I am thinking of doing this on a Friday night because itâ€™s the end of the work week and we can all have a relaxing evening. We will be playing in the living room so it feels cozier. I wish to invite them over in order to spend more quality time with them and strengthen our relationships.

I would love to invite a few close friends for a movie marathon in my home. Going to invite my friends who share a love for classic movies like me. We usually meet up on Sundays because it is the most free day for all of us. The marathon will be held in my home theater for optimal viewing experience. My purpose for this gathering is to share and relive some of our favorite classic films together.

topics: Do you prefer to spend time with one friend or with a group of friends?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions

Who are you more comfortable with, one friend or a group of friends? Consider your level of comfort, the depth of connection you enjoy, and how intimate or personal your conversations can get.

What are your preferred activities? Reflect on whether these are more suitable for large groups or a more intimate gathering.

When you're with a group, do you feel more energized or drained? Think about your levels of energy and enthusiasm in both settings.

Where do you prefer to meet friends? Some places might be more suited to larger groups, while others are cozier for smaller meet-ups.

Why do you prefer one over the other? This could involve elements of social anxiety, crowd management, or the simplicity of interaction.

Example Answers

I deeply cherish the connections I form with individuals, and thus I am more comfortable spending time with just one friend. Our conversations are often more raw, personal, and meaningful. Additionally, I find that I am more energized after these meet-ups, whereas groups tend to drain me due to the need for more social management. Due to this, the quiet corners of cozy cafes are where I find the most solace.

Being an extrovert, I thrive in groups. Theyâ€™re exciting and dynamic, each person adding a unique flavor. Not only do I enjoy the camaraderie, but I also love the energy dynamics within the group. Iâ€™m intrigued by the collective problem-solving or brainstorming that happens, and I adore big, festive gatherings at larger, more spacious venues.

I relish the balance between intimacy and variety, so my preference fluctuates. When I crave deep conversations and emotional connection, I favor the company of one friend. However, if I'm in the mood for fun, exhilaration, and a lively atmosphere, a group rendezvous is my go-to. Therefore, both quiet, tranquil parks and louder, bustling restaurants are my favored locales.

topics: Do you have a friend you have known for a long time?
solutions:
Section One: WH-Questions and Suggestions

Who is your long-time friend?

Suggestions: name, occupation, general description

When did you first meet this friend?

Suggestions: during childhood, in high school, at university

Where did you meet this friend?

Suggestions: school, neighborhood, online platforms

What are some shared memories with this friend?

Suggestions: memorable trips, significant life events, funny incidents

Why do you consider him/her as your long-time friend?

Suggestions: shared interests, trust, mutual support

Section Two: Example Answers

My long-time friend is John. We first crossed paths during our high school days. Our friendship commenced in the 9th standard when we were in the same class. John, now an engineer, remains my buddy who stood by me through thick and thin. Weâ€™ve made countless unforgettable memories, from pulling all-nighters for exams to embarking on daring adventures.

Mary is my oldest friend. We met on an online platform about 15 years ago and bonded over shared interests in art and music, despite living thousands of miles apart. She's an artist now and we have shared countless virtual and personal memories together. Our consistent communication and mutual support have turned our friendship into a lifelong bond.

I met Sarah in my neighborhood when we were kids. For more than two decades now, she has been my consistent comrade. Our friendship bloomed from shared sandbox games to attending the same university and now, navigating through our careers. Despite the physical distance between us, our bond has only grown stronger over the years.

topics: What do you usually do with your friends?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and Suggestions

What activities do you frequently participate in with your friends? - Sports, movie nights, dinners, study sessions.

Where do you usually meet up with your friends? - Cafes, parks, friends' houses, concert halls.

When do you usually spend time with your friends? - Weekends, after school or work, holidays.

Why do you enjoy hanging out with your friends? - Shared interests, witty conversations, feeling of camaraderie.

Who are the friends you usually hang out with? - School friends, colleagues, childhood friends, online friends.

Section 2: Example Answers

I often meet up with my friends - usually my closest school friends - at cafes in the city after school or work. We enjoy hanging out together because we share many common interests, such as a love for music and books. The witty and insightful conversations we have are always a highlight of my day.

My friends and I typically spend our weekends together. We usually gather at one friend's house, alternating every week. The group mostly consists of my childhood friends and a few colleagues. Our common hobby is playing board games. I enjoy these meetups, as the friendly competition creates a feeling of camaraderie among us.

Whenever the holidays roll around, I traditionally go on trips with a group of my close friends. We like to explore different parts of the country, or sometimes even travel abroad. These experiences are always enjoyable as it strengthens our bond even further and gives us memories to look back on.

topics: Where do you often meet each other?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and suggestions

Where do you often meet each other?
Suggestions: location, city, building, coffee shop, park, gym, office, online platforms like Zoom.

When do you often meet each other?
Suggestions: weekdays, weekends, morning, evenings, during lunch breaks.

Why do you often meet each other at that particular place?
Suggestions: convenience, proximity, ambiance, facilities, liking.

Who do you often meet?
Suggestions: friends, family members, colleagues, partners, clients.

Section 2: Example Answers

We often meet at a local coffee shop in downtown. This shop is centrally located and easily accessible by everyone. Plus, we all love their coffee and cozy ambiance which makes it the perfect place to catch up.

We meet each weekend at our neighborhood park. The park provides a refreshing and relaxed environment. We enjoy our group workouts here and sometimes play a game or two. It's a place where we de-stress and rejuvenate for the next week.

Our team often meets online on Zoom nowadays due to the pandemic. We meet every Friday afternoon to discuss the week's updates and plan for the next. It's easier and safer to meet virtually in the current scenario.

topics: Do you often go out with your friends?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions

Who do you usually go out with? (names of friends, classmates, colleagues, relatives)

What activities do you do when you go out? (dinner, movies, shopping, hiking, parties)

Where do you often go? (restaurants, cafes, parks, friends' houses, city center, malls)

When do you usually hang out? (weekends, after work, holidays, every couple of weeks)

Why do you like going out with your friends? (to relax, have fun, escape boredom, maintain social relationships)

How often do you go out with your friends? (three times a week, once a month, every weekend, occasionally)

Sample Answers

I usually go out with my closest friends, who are my college classmates. We love catching up over dinner at local restaurants or food joints and sometimes we feel adventurous and try out new places. We mostly hang out during the weekends or sometimes after work. For me, it's a great way to relax and maintain our friendship.

I go out with my friends once a week, usually over the weekend. We take turns suggesting different activities but we most often end up watching a movie or shopping. I think itâ€™s because these activities give us the chance to relax, enjoy ourselves, and bond over common interests.

I do not go out with my friends too often, as we all have very busy schedules. When we do manage to find a common free day, usually during a holiday, we like to go hiking or simply chill at one of our houses. For me, these outings are refreshing breaks from my routine and they help to strengthen our bond.

topics: How important are friends to you?
solutions:
Section One: WH-Questions and Suggestions

What roles do friends play in your life?

Suggestions: Emotional support, Shared experiences, Personal growth

Why do you value your friendships?

Suggestions: Happiness, Company, Trust and loyalty, Understanding

Which friend has made the most impact in your life and how?

Suggestions: Guidance, mentorship, Positivity, Life-changing experience

Section Two: Examples

Friends play a vital role in my life as they offer emotional support, enable shared experiences which bring joy, and contribute to personal growth. They are the ones I turn to when times are tough and they provide much-needed reassurance or advice.

I value my friendships because they bring happiness into my life. The company of my friends provides a welcome escape from the daily grind. Trust and loyalty are fundamental in my relationships, and it's these qualities I hold dear in my friends. They genuinely understand me for who I am, which brings a great deal of comfort.

Out of all my friends, Jane has had the biggest impact on my life. Her positivity and zest for life are truly infectious. She has guided me through some of the roughest patches of my life, acting as both a mentor and a friend. Our friendship has been a life-changing experience.

topics: Which do you prefer, reading books or watching movies?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and Suggestions

What kind of stories do you most enjoy?

Examples: Romantic novels, thrillers, historical films, sci-fi movies

Why do you prefer one over the other?

Examples: More detailed descriptions, ability to imagine, easily accessible, visual effects

When do you usually read or watch movies?

Examples: Before bed, weekends, during commutes, in spare time

How does your choice affect your daily life and convenience?

Examples: Portable, takes up more time, requires a setup and specific environment

Section 2: Example Answers

I prefer reading books as I have always enjoyed the detailed descriptions and elaborate storytelling provided in novels. Books inspire my imagination and make me think deeper about the plots and characters. I usually read before bedtime as it helps me to relax, although it does take up more of my spare time compared to watching movies.

As a fan of visual effects and graphic storytelling, watching movies is my preference. Their ability to express stories vividly through images and sounds fascinates me. Moreover, I often watch movies during weekends when I have spare time. Despite requiring a TV setup, it is a more easily accessible form of entertainment for me.

I typically lean towards reading books more as I love the sense of anticipation and the thrill of turning each page. I find it much more satisfying than watching movies, especially when it comes to mystery and thriller genres. I often read during my commute, which makes it a convenient choice for me even though it can be less immersive than watching movies.

topics: Have you ever read a novel that has been adapted into a film?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and Suggestions

What is the novel's title and who is the author?

Suggestions: Name of the book, author's name

Who directed the film adaptation and who starred in it?

Suggestions: Director's name, main actors and actresses

When was the novel published and when was the film released?

Suggestions: Publication date, film release date

How does the film differ from the novel?

Suggestions: Differences in plot, characters, themes, or settings

Did you enjoy the book more than the film, or vice versa?

Suggestions: Personal opinion, comparison, reasons

Section 2: Examples

The novel I read was "The Great Gatsby" by F. Scott Fitzgerald. The film adaptation was directed by Baz Luhrmann, and it starred Leonardo DiCaprio as Jay Gatsby. The novel was published in 1925, while the film was released in 2013. There were some differences between the film and the novel, such as the use of modern music in the film. Personally, I enjoyed the novel more because of its immersive descriptions and intricate character relationships.

One of the novels I've read that was adapted into a film is "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone" by J.K. Rowling. The film was directed by Chris Columbus and starred Daniel Radcliffe as Harry Potter. The book was published in 1997, and the film was released in 2001. The main difference between the book and the film was that some minor scenes from the book were excluded from the film. I loved both the book and the film equally as they both provide different experiences to the story.

I have read "The Hunger Games" by Suzanne Collins, which was adapted into a movie. The film was directed by Gary Ross and Jennifer Lawrence played the lead role as Katniss Everdeen. The novel was published in 2008, and the film was released in 2012. The film stayed quite true to the book but certain backstories were missing, making the characters in the movie a bit less developed. I enjoyed the book more as it gave more insight into Katniss's thoughts and feelings.

topics: Are your reading habits now different than before?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and Suggestions

What genres or authors do you read now compared to before?

Suggestions: types of books, favorite authors, evolution of taste.

When do you find time to read now and how has it changed over time?

Suggestions: reading schedule, time management, changes in daily routine.

Where do you usually read your books now as opposed to before?

Suggestions: favorite reading spots, change in environment, comfort places.

Why have these changes occured?

Suggestions: shift of interests, lifestyle changes, career advancements.

How have your reading habits affected your life?

Suggestions: influence on personal life, effects on career, impacts on relationships.

Section 2: Sample Answers

Compared to my earlier days, I have made a massive shift in my reading tastes. What I appreciate more now are metaphysical and philosophical books, it's quite different from the fantasy toggles I used to drown myself in. Authors like Eckhart Tolle and Deepak Chopra have taken places of J.K. Rowling and J.R.R. Tolkien on my reading list.

As a result of my demanding career, when I read has significantly changed. I now have a specific time devoted for reading - an hour before sleep. As opposed to my previous unstructured and sporadic reading hours, I have found this approach more comforting and rewarding.

Occasionally, I read at local library on weekends or sometimes even in a quiet park. Interestingly, I wasn't very particular about where I read before. Whether it was in a bustling cafÃ© or in the comfort of my bed, as long as I had a book, everything else blurred out.Â

topics: Do you often read books? When?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and Suggestions

WH-questions:
1. When do you usually read books?
2. What types of books do you prefer reading?
3. Where do you like to read books?
4. Why do you choose to read books?
5. How often do you read books?

Suggestions in Phrases and Words:
Every evening, biographies, in my home study, for expanding knowledge, once a week, on the commute, thrillers, escape reality, twice a day, historical fiction, in the park, for leisure, every month, how-to books, at the library, for self-improvement, thrice a week.

Section 2: Examples of Responses

Example 1: I usually read books every evening. My preference leans towards biographies as I am intrigued by people's lives and experiences. I enjoy reading in the tranquility of my home study, it helps me absorb the text better. The main reason I choose to read books is to expand my knowledge and understanding.

Example 2: I have formed a habit of reading books on my commute to work, at least twice a day. I find thrillers captivating as they keep me engaged and make my travel time enjoyable. Reading allows me to escape the reality of a crowded train and immerse myself in an alternate world.

Example 3: I read books somewhat infrequently, about once every month. I enjoy historical fiction as they allow me to explore different time periods and cultures. My favorite place to read is nestled under a tree in the park. I choose to read for leisure, giving me moments of peace in a busy schedule.

topics: Do you read more or less now than when you were younger?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions for Phrases and Words

What types of books or articles do you read more now?

Suggestions: novels, newspapers, scientific research papers, magazines, eBooks

When do you find you read the most compared to when you were younger?

Suggestions: during commute, before bed, weekends, mornings

Why do you think your reading habits have changed?

Suggestions: job requirements, educational purposes, personal interest, lack of spare time, the growth of digital device usage

How much time do you spend reading now as opposed to when you were younger?

Suggestions: hours per day, books per month

Examples:

In comparison to when I was younger, my reading habits have significantly increased. What I read, however, has shifted from mostly fiction novels to a more diverse range of subjects including scientific research papers, news articles, and books related to my field of work. When I read has also changed, as I now tend to read most often during my daily commute and before bedtime. This drastic shift in my reading habits is largely due to the demands of my job and my interest in ongoing learning.

My reading habits have remained rather consistent since my younger years. What I read has marginally shifted; now, it involves more industry-specific articles and books, as opposed to the general knowledge or fiction I used to indulge in during college. When has not essentially changed, as I still make time to read during my leisure hours. The prime reason for this consistency is my enduring love for books and reading.

While I used to be an avid reader as a child, as an adult, I find myself reading considerably less. In my early years, books were an escape and my main form of entertainment. I would spend countless hours immersed in various fantasy novels. Now, I find myself reading more work-related articles and informative blogs. My reading is no longer restricted to leisure hours; it now forms a significant part of my professional life. This shift can be attributed to a change in why I read - from pleasure to knowledge acquisition.

topics: Do you like the morning or evening?
solutions:
WH-questions and Suggestions for Answering "Do you like the morning or evening?"

What do you enjoy about the morning or evening? (activities, weather, peacefulness)

When do you feel most productive or inspired, in the morning or evening? (work performance, creativity, attentiveness)

Where do you like to spend time in the morning or evening? (indoor, outdoor, favorite locations)

Why do you prefer the morning or evening? (physical feeling, mood, personal beliefs)

Examples of Answers

I really appreciate the calmness of the evening. After a long day of work, there's nothing more satisfying than winding down with a good book or a movie. I also find that the cooler temperatures make it the perfect time for a quiet walk in my neighbourhood.

I am definitely a morning person. I love starting my day with some light exercise and meditation. I find that this routine not only energizes me for the rest of the day but also helps me maintain a positive mood. Also, I feel most productive in the morning when my mind is fresh.

I enjoy both the morning and evening for different reasons. In the morning, I love how the world seems to wake up with me, it fills me with motivation to start the day. Whereas, the evening is when I have time for myself and my hobbies. Overall, it's the balance of both that I cherish.

topics: What do you usually do in the eveningï¼Ÿ
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and suggestions

What hobbies or activities do you engage in during the evening? Suggestions: watching TV, reading, cooking, exercising, gardening, playing video games

Who do you usually spend your evenings with? Suggestions: family, friends, pets, alone

Where do you usually spend your evenings? Suggestions: home, a friend's house, gym, park, restaurant, club

When do your evening activities usually start and end? Suggestions: After work, after dinner, before bedtime

Why do you choose these activities to do in the evenings? Suggestions: Relaxation, fitness, socializing, education, entertainment

Section 2: Example answers

In the evening, I usually engage in activities that allow me to unwind after a day's work. What I like to do is cook a nice dinner for myself, then settle down with a good book or watch a movie. Where I spend my evening is usually at home, it's my special quiet time. These activities usually start after work, around 7pm. Why I choose these activities? Because they help me relax and recharge for the next day.

During the evenings, What I usually do is hit the gym for a few hours, and then hang out with my friends at a nearby bar. Who I spend the evening with depends on who is available, but I am usually never alone. Where I spend my evening changes, but it's typically outside. These activities start after work, around 6pm. I choose these activities as I find that it helps me stay fit and social.

What I usually do in the evening is spend quality time with my family. We usually eat dinner together, play board games or watch TV. Who I spend my evenings with is my spouse and our two kids. Where we spend our evenings is usually in the living room of our house. These activities usually start after dinner, at around 7:30pm. Why I choose these activities? Because family time is very important to me.

topics: What did you do in the evening when you were little? Why?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions

What hobbies or activities did you engage in during the evenings when you were little?

Suggestions: playing games, watching TV, drawing, playing with toys, reading books

Who did you spend your evenings with when you were little?

Suggestions: family, friends, siblings, alone

Where did you usually spend your evenings when you were little?

Suggestions: home, park, friend's house, grandparents' house

When in the evening did you usually do these activities?

Suggestions: right after school, after dinner, before bedtime

Why did you do these specific activities in the evening?

Suggestions: to relax, to have fun, to learn something new

Examples

When I was little, I used to spend my evenings playing board games with my siblings. It was our favourite activity because it was a fun way to spend time together and we loved the friendly competition. Right after dinner, we would gather around the living room and play until bedtime.

As a child, I used to spend my evenings at my grandparents' house. They lived nearby and I loved being with them. My grandmother used to tell me stories while my grandfather taught me how to play chess. These evening sessions not only helped me to bond with my grandparents, but also ignited my interest in storytelling and strategy games.

I used to spend my evenings reading books when I was a kid. I had an insatiable thirst for learning new things and books were my gateway to knowledge. I remember sitting in my room, engrossed in a new adventure or learning about the world. These reading sessions sparked my curiosity, fueling my passion for reading and learning that I carry forward even today.

topics: Are there any differences between what you do in the evening now and what you did in the past?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and Suggestions

What activities did you used to enjoy in your evenings in the past?

- Suggestions: Reading, Watching TV, Playing outside, Gaming, Socializing with friends.

Where did you often spend your evenings in the past?

- Suggestions: At home, In a friend's house, At a pub or bar, At the park.

Who did you often spend your evenings with in the past?

- Suggestions: Family, Friends, Alone.

Why did you prefer those activities?

- Suggestions: Relaxation, Entertainment, Enjoyment, Exercise.

How did you often end your evenings in the past?

- Suggestions: Going to bed early, Staying up late, Movies.
Section 2: Examples

In the past, I used to spend my evenings reading a book in a quiet corner of my home. I was not as distracted by digital media as I am now. Plus, my circle of friends was smaller, so I had more unwinding time by myself.

I often spent my evenings at the local pub with friends a few years back. We'd share a drink and talk about our day. It was a form of stress relief and a great way to maintain close relationships. Now, I spend more evenings at home, focusing on personal projects and goals.

My evenings used to end pretty late in the past, typically spent gaming with online friends. I enjoyed the thrill and competition. These days, I'm more inclined to head to bed early to ensure I get enough sleep for my morning routines and work.

topics: Do you spend your evenings doing the same things on both weekends and weekdays? Why?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and Suggestions

What activities do you typically do in the evening during weekdays and weekends?

Suggest phrases and words: Work-related tasks, household chores, rest and relaxation, hobbies, TV or Netflix, reading, exercise

When do you usually start these activities and how much time do you spend on each?

Suggest phrases and words: Immediately after work, before dinner, after dinner, 1-2 hours, several minutes, the whole evening

Why do you choose these activities to spend your evenings?

Suggest phrases and words: Relaxation, unwinding, stress relief, personal growth, entertainment, passion, physical and mental health, family time

Who are you usually with during these activities?

Suggest phrases and words: Alone, family, partner, friends, colleagues
Section 2: Answer Examples

During the weekdays, I usually spend my evenings doing work-related tasks for a couple of hours after dinner. However, on the weekends, I spend the evenings relaxing and watching movies on Netflix. The reason being, I need to catch up on work during the weekdays and the weekends are my time to unwind.

Unlike the weekdays when I'm often swamped with house chores and work, my weekend evenings are quite different. I spend them working on my hobby - painting. Sometimes, I'd spend the whole evening perfecting a piece. This time alone is vital for my stress relief and allows me to express my creativity.

On weekdays, I typically spend time with my family in the evenings. We would have dinner together and sometimes watch a TV show afterwards. Over the weekend, however, I would often catch up with friends over drinks or a movie. These activities give me a balance between my family time during the weekdays and socialising over the weekends.

topics: When you were a kid, did you usually sit on the floor?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and Suggestions

When did you often sit on the floor as a child?

Suggestions: at home, during school, at friends' houses

Where were your preferred spots to sit on the floor?

Suggestions: in the living room, in the bedroom, in the kitchen

Why did you choose to sit on the floor?

Suggestions: to play games, to draw, to watch television

Section 2: Example Answers

When I was a kid, I often sat on the floor when I was at home, especially in the evenings. My brother and I would gather in the living room and play board games, with the floor serving as our main playing area. We found it so much more exciting and fun to sprawl out on the carpet than to restrict ourselves to a table.

As a child, I had a few favorite spots where I loved to sit on the floor. One of them was right in front of the television in the living room because it felt like having a private movie theater. I also liked sitting on the kitchen floor while my mom cooked dinner, peering up at her and occasionally being allowed to assist in small tasks.

I sat on the floor most of the time because, as a kid, I felt a stronger connection with the ground. Sitting on the floor provided me with a greater sense of freedom; I could easily rearrange my position, spread out my toys, or lounging to watch TV. There was something fundamentally fun about being closer to the ground, and this simple act brought me a lot of joy and comfort.

topics: Do you feel sleepy when you are sitting down?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions for Answering "Do you feel sleepy when you are sitting down?"

When do you often feel sleepy while sitting down? - 'after meals', 'during monotonous tasks', 'at night', 'during lectures'.

What activities are you doing when you feel sleepy? - 'watching TV', 'reading', 'studying', 'work meetings'.

Where are you usually sitting when you get sleepy? - 'at home', 'in school', 'in the office', 'in transport'.

Who are you with when you feel sleepy sitting down? - 'alone', 'with family', 'among friends', 'with colleagues'.

Why do you think you feel sleepy when you sit down? - 'distracted easily', 'tired', 'bored', 'comfortable'.

Examples

Generally, I tend to feel sleepy after eating a heavy meal, especially while sitting down to watch TV or relaxing at home. It seems digestion process takes a good amount of my energy, making me lethargic and sleepy.

When I am sitting down during monotonous work meetings, I often find myself getting sleepy. This usually happens in the post-lunch work hours and more when I am in a group as my attention wanes easily.

I often catch myself feeling unusually drowsy during mid-afternoon hours, mostly when I am sitting in my office, surrounded by my colleagues. I guess it's my body's natural response to the circadian rhythm and the comfortable and quiet atmosphere simply adds to it.

topics: Do you always sit down for a long time?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and Suggestions

Who usually sits with you during this time? (family members, colleagues, friends, alone)

What activity are you usually engaged in when you sit down for a long time? (working, studying, watching tv, reading, travelling)

When do you usually sit down for a long time? (morning, afternoon, evening, night)

Where do you usually sit down for a long time? (office, home, public transportation, cafe)

Why do you usually sit down for a long time? (work requirements, relaxation, enjoyment of a particular activity)

Section 2: Example Answers

I usually sit down for a long time when I'm working. Ain't alone though, I work in a shared office space, so I'm usually surrounded by my colleagues. This occurs mostly in the mornings and afternoons when I'm at my office. The nature of my job demands me to work on a computer, so I end up sitting for a long time.

I have a long commute, so I sit for a long time on public transportation. This usually happens to me in the mornings and evenings, during my way to and back from work. There's not much company at that time other than fellow commuters who too, like me, are on their way to work or home.

I have a habit of reading a lot, so during my free time, mainly in the evenings and nights, I end up sitting for a long time. This takes place mostly at my home, in my study, where I enjoy a quiet time with my books. It's my way of relaxing after a tiring day.

topics: Where is your favorite place to sit?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions

What kind of seating do you prefer? For example airy, cozy, spacious etc.

Where is the location of your seating? Such as in the garden, by the window, in the library etc.

Why do you like this spot? Explanations could include peacefulness, view, mental relaxation etc.

When do you typically sit there? It could be anytime, during work, morning coffee, reading etc.

Who are you usually with? You could be alone, with friends, family, or your pet.

Examples

For me, my favorite place to sit is on the rocking chair on my porch. I love it particularly in the evenings when the sun is setting. The calmness of the surrounding helps me relax and I enjoy having a cup of tea there with my pet dog. The view of the sun setting makes me appreciate the beauty of nature.

My favorite place to sit is in the corner of my library on my comfy chair. This place offers me a quiet space, perfect for getting lost in a good book or for brainstorming ideas for my projects. I usually sit there early in the morning before the hustle of the day kicks in. The soft morning sunlight combined with the smell of books creates a serene and inspiring atmosphere.

I prefer to sit on the terrace of my house. It's at a height from where I can look at the sprawling town and the distant mountains. I usually sit there after my dinner for some fresh air and star-gazing. It's a quiet spot which provides me an escape from a hustling day. Frequently, I share this quiet moment with my partner as we both enjoy our late night conversations here.

topics: In what conditions would it be difficult for you to use a computer?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions

What types of physical conditions could make computer usage difficult?

Suggestions: Limited hand mobility, vision impairment, severe arthritis, carpal tunnel syndrome.

Where are some locations where using a computer may be challenging?

Suggestions: Outdoors in bright sunlight, in remote locations without electricity, in wet or dusty environments.

When could time-based conditions hinder computer usage?

Suggestions: During power outages, in areas with limited or no internet connectivity, during systems' maintenance or upgrades.

Example Answers

One situation wherein it would be difficult for me to use a computer is if I were to have physical conditions such as limited hand mobility or severe arthritisâ€”which can impair typing and mouse useâ€”or vision impairment, which might prevent me from seeing the screen or text clearly. Thus, individuals with these conditions might require accessibility tools or devices to use a computer properly.

If I were in a location with harsh environmental conditions, like in the dessert with glaring sunlight or a heavy dust storm, using a computer would be tough. Bright light can cause glare on the screen, making it difficult to see, while dust can damage the computer hardware. Similarly, using a computer could be unfeasible in environments without reliable electricity source to power the device.

If it's during a power outage or in an area with limited or no internet connectivity, using a computer would be challenging. Computers rely on electricity, and many computer activities require internet. Moreover, using a computer during system maintenance or upgrades can be difficult or impossible if the operating system or software applications are temporarily unavailable.

topics: What would your life be like without computers?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and Suggestions

What major changes would occur in your life without computers? - Physical communication, traditional methods, offline activities.

Why would the lack of computers affect your daily routines? - Dependency on technology, speed, efficiency, communication.

How would you communicate without emails or social media? - Letters, face-to-face interactions, phone calls.

Where would you gather information without the internet? - Books, newspapers, libraries, people.

Who would you interact with more if not spending time with computers? - Friends, family, neighbors, colleagues.

Section 2: Sample Answers

Without computers, my life would undergo several significant changes. I would have to rely on face-to-face conversations and physical letters for communication, which would slow down the pace of my personal and work communications considerably. Additionally, I would spend more time engaging in offline activities like reading books, playing sports, or going out with friends.

If I didn't have access to computers, it would heavily affect my daily routines. This is because I rely on my computer not only for work tasks due to its speed and efficiency but also for communication and entertainment. Also, without the instant information access provided by the internet, I would be dependent on newspapers, books, or people for information.

Without the computer, my communication methods would shift radically. I would have to revert back to writing letters, making phone calls, or having face-to-face interactions. This might be time-consuming but could also be more personal and meaningful. Without spending time on the computer, I would interact more with people in my physical surroundings like family, friends, and colleagues.

topics: When was the first time you used a computer?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and Suggestions

When did you first use a computer? (Year, age, period of life)

Where did you first use a computer? (Place, environment, setting)

Why did you first use a computer? (Reason, purpose, necessity)

What was your first experience with using a computer? (Activity, software used, type of computer)

Who introduced you to your first computer? (Person, relationship, profession)

Section 2: Example Answers

The first time I used a computer was back in the late 1990s. My parents had just bought one for the family when I was about 10 years old. We had it installed in the living room of our house in Boston. Our neighbour, who was a high school computer teacher, helped set it up and taught me how to use some basic programs. I often used the Paint program, and I remember being thrilled by the different colors and shapes I could create.

I first encountered a computer in my 7th-grade classroom. It was around 2005, and our school had just received a set of computers for education purposes. We were taught how to use them by our computer science teacher. My first activity on the computer was a typing practice software. It was intimidating at first, but then I found it incredibly fascinating.

I used a computer for the first time during my first job as a data entry clerk in the early 2000s. Located in a small office in downtown Miami, the computer was an old model, running on Windows 98. My supervisor, a tech-savvy person, showed me the basics of spreadsheet management. Although the work was repetitive, it sparked my interest in the world of technology.

topics: In what conditions would you use a computer?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and Suggestions

When would you need to use a computer?

Suggestions: Weekly tasks, daily tasks, office work, schoolwork, project deadlines

Where are you when you most often use your computer?

Suggestions: At home, in the office, at school, in a coffee shop, in a library

Why do you use a computer?

Suggestions: Writing emails, designing graphics, software development, online shopping, gaming, learning online

Who uses the computer in your house?

Suggestions: You, your children, your parents, your siblings, your friends

What types of tasks do you complete on your computer?

Suggestions: Writing assignments, work projects, coding tasks, creating digital art, browsing social media

Section 2: Examples

Example 1: When do you use your computer? I use my computer daily for a variety of tasks. This includes checking and responding to my emails, drafting up reports for work, and doing online researches. In the evening, I often use it to watch movies or play games.

Example 2: What types of tasks do you complete on your computer? I often use my computer for various professional and leisure activities. During business hours, I usually create presentations and analyze data. However, during my downtime, I use my computer for things like browsing social media, shopping online or gaming.

Example 3: Where are you when you use your computer? I mostly use my computer at home where I have a dedicated workspace. At times, I might take it to a local coffee shop if I need a change of scenery. When travel is required for work, I use my computer in hotels or conference rooms.

topics: Are there any old buildings you want to see in the future? Why?
solutions:
Section 1: WH Questions and Suggestions

WH-questions:

- What is the historical significance of the old building you want to see?

- When was the old building you want to visit built?

- Why are you interested in visiting this particular old building?

- Where is this old building located?

- Who were the key figures involved in the construction or history of the old building?

Suggestions in phrases and words:

- Architectural styles

- Historical events associated with the building

- Cultural significance

- Personal interest or fascination

- Connection to famous historical personalities

Section 2: Example Answers

I would love to see the Colosseum in Rome, Italy. The historical significance of this old building is tremendous as it is not only a symbol of the Ancient Roman civilization but also a testament to the incredible architectural skills of the Romans. The Colosseum, built around 70-80 AD, was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles. Plus, being a history enthusiast, visiting such an iconic structure would be a dream come true for me.

The ancient Pyramids of Giza in Egypt are among the old structures that I am intrigued to see. These pyramids, built in 2600 BC, are one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. Their geometric precision and the mystery surrounding their construction still puzzle researchers and archaeologists. More so, the Pyramids represent the ingeniousness of the Ancient Egyptian civilization.

One old building that I want to see in the future is the Great Wall of China. Stretching over 21,000 kilometres, it was built across several centuries to protect Chinese states against invasions. I want to visit this historic and iconic site because it is a remarkable human achievement and a symbol of perseverance. Plus, it provides stunning natural views and promises an adventurous trekking experience.

topics: Do you prefer living in an old building or a modern houseï¼Ÿ
solutions:
Section One: WH-Questions and Suggestions

What are the aesthetic preferences for your living environment?

Suggestions: historical charm, clean lines, minimalist design, ornate architectural details

When was the building or house built?

Suggestions: date of construction, era-specific styles, technological advancements

Why is your preference towards one or the other?

Suggestions: comfort factors, modern amenities, nostalgic value, maintenance requirements

Who will be living in the house?

Suggestions: growing family, single occupant, older individuals, meetings the needs of the occupants

Where is the building or house located?

Suggestions: urban area, rural settings, access to necessities, schools, and workplaces

Section Two: Examples

I prefer living in an old building because of the historical charm and nostalgic value it brings. The ornate architectural details prevalent in older buildings provide a unique personality that modern houses sometimes lack. However, modern amenities can be lacking, and maintenance can be higher.

Growing up in a modern home, I've always loved the clean lines and minimalist design. Technological advancements are often found in newer construction, providing greater comfort and convenience. However, it's essential to consider the location as modern houses in urban areas can still suffer from noise and congestion.

With a growing family, a modern house is my preference. These homes often feature open-concept living spaces, making it easier to keep an eye on children. The recent builds usually have better energy efficiency, which can lead to savings on utility costs. Despite the love for historical charm, practicality and functionality are the priority for my family at this stage.

topics: Do you think we should preserve old buildings in citiesï¼Ÿ
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions

Why should we preserve old buildings in cities? - Perspectives, historical relevance, architectural significance.

What contributions do old buildings make to the city's identity? - Character, aesthetics, cultural context, identity of the city.

Who benefits from the preservation of old buildings? - Community, tourists, historians, city dwellers.

When have old buildings been successfully integrated into modern urban planning? - Success stories, case studies, examples of preservation.

How can old buildings be adapted for modern use? - Retrofitting, adaptive reuse, sustainable practices.

Example Answers

Perspectives on why we should preserve old buildings in cities often focus on their historical relevance and architectural significance. Reflecting the different periods of a city's history, these structures offer a tangible link to our past, telling stories of the people, events, and ideas that shaped our world. Architecturally, they might showcase craftsmanship, materials, and design sensibilities no longer prevalent today.

Old buildings contribute greatly to a city's unique character and aesthetic appeal, providing a sense of continuity and cultural context that enriches the living experience of city dwellers and attracts tourists. For instance, the preserved Victorian-era architecture in San Francisco lends the city a distinct identity, admired and enjoyed all over the world.

Successful integration of old buildings into modern urban planning can be seen in cities like London and Rome, where historic structures coexist harmoniously with contemporary design. In London, for instance, the Tower of London and St. Paul's Cathedral are key elements of the city's skyline, alongside modern skyscrapers like the Shard. These preserved buildings serve as reminders of the city's rich history while enhancing its modern appeal.

topics: Have you ever seen old buildings in the cityï¼Ÿ
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and Suggestions

What types of old buildings have you seen in the city? (e.g. historical, residential, commercial, governmental)

Where are these old buildings located in the city? (e.g. central downtown, suburbs, specific neighborhoods)

When were these buildings constructed? (e.g. 19th century, early 20th century, late 20th century)

Who are the notable people or events associated with these old buildings? (e.g. famous architects, historical events, formers occupants)

Why do these old buildings matter? (e.g. historical importance, architectural value, cultural significance)

Section 2: Example Responses

I have seen many old buildings in the city- from modern constructions to heritage ones. What really stands out is the old City Hall, an architectural marvel from the 19th century. It is located at the heart of the city, a stone throw away from the city center. A named architect was behind its construction, lending it a design that makes it stand out even today. The building holds special significance, hosting the city's administration for over a century.

The old buildings I've seen in the city are quite remarkable. They're scattered across the city, from the bustling downtown to the quiet suburbs. Where these buildings are located seems to tell their own story, from the grand old theatres and museums in the city centre, to the ornate Victorian-style houses in the outlying areas. The difference in style and age between the buildings from different areas is quite striking, and they provide a unique identity to each neighborhood.

Many old buildings in the city have such a rich history. When they were built gives us a glimpse into the city's past. For instance, the charming rows of 20th-century brownstone townhouses, or the imposing 19th-century government buildings, they all represent different periods in our city's development. Each one has a unique story to tell, showcasing the cultural progression and architectural evolution over the years.

topics: Where do you usually keep things you need?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and Suggestions

Where do you usually store items that you frequently use? Possible responses include: on my desk, in my purse, in a drawer or cabinet, in a specific room, etc.

What specific items do you regularly need and where do you keep them? Suggestions could include: mobile phone on the bedside table, stationery in the desk drawer, keys on a hook by the front door, etc.

When and why do you usually need these items? Potential circumstances might be: upon waking up, during work or school, meal preparation, going out, etc.

Section 2: Examples

Example 1: I typically keep the items I regularly use, such as my laptop, phone and notebook, on my desk. This location is convenient for me since it's where I spend most of my time working and studying.

Example 2: I often need my reading glasses when I am reading or working on my computer. Therefore, I usually keep them on my office desk or beside the book I am currently reading at home.

Example 3: When I am cooking, I often need a variety of kitchen tools and ingredients. Thus, I keep things like pots, pans, and cutting boards in the kitchen cabinets, while common spices, oils, and other essentials are kept on a spice rack near the stove for easy access.

topics: Would you keep old things for a long time? Why?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and Suggestions

What kind of items may hold sentimental value? - old photos, letters, personal diaries, heirlooms.

When did you acquire these objects? - childhood, adolescence, adulthood, inherited.

Who gave you these items? - family, friends, significant others.

Why are these items valuable to you? - memories, emotional connections, historical significance.

How do you manage and preserve them? - storage methods, cleaning and maintenance, safe environments.

Section 2: Examples

I would keep old things for a long time, for example an old photo album that I inherited from my grandmother. It holds sentimental value to me because it brings back beautiful memories of my family. The photos were taken when I was a child. They capture precious moments with my loved ones and remind me of the good old days. To preserve the album, I regularly dust it and keep it in a cool, dry place.

I've kept the letters that my best friend sent me whilst she was abroad. The letters aren't just pieces of paper to me, they represent our friendship and shared experiences. I received these letters in my late adolescence, a period of my life that was filled with growth and change. I manage these letters by keeping them secured in a special box to prevent any damage.

One of my most cherished items is a wrist watch that was given to me by my father on my 20th birthday. It serves as a reminder of the immense love and support my father provided me throughout my life. The watch is worn and somewhat old-fashioned, yet I keep it safe and intact as it continues to remind me of my father's kindness and love whenever I look at it.

topics: Are there any things you have kept from your childhood?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions for Answering

What childhood items do you still have? An old blanket, favorite toys, comic books...

Where do you store your childhood items? In a special box, in the attic, in your room...

Why have you kept those particular items from your childhood? Because they bring back good memories, they have sentimental value, they belong to someone special...

Example Answers

I still have a couple of stuffed animals that I used to play with as a child. They are old and bit worn-out, but whenever I look at them, they instantly bring back memories of my carefree childhood days. I keep them safe in a box in my room and every now and then, I take them out just to reminisce those golden times.

My childhood wouldn't be complete without mentioning the collection of comic books I still possess. I was an avid reader and my comic books were my treasured possessions. I've kept them safe over the years in the attic. They remain a tangible link to simpler and innocent times of my life.

I have kept a blanket from my childhood. It's faded and torn at places, yet it holds so many memories. It was a gift from my grandmother, which adds to its sentimental value. Iâ€™ve kept it as a valuable memento, stashed away in my closet, reminding me of her love and warmth every time I see it.

topics: Do you collect things?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and Suggestions

What do you collect? (Coins, stamps, postcards, memorabilia, etc.)

Why did you start collecting these items? (Interest, passion, as a hobby, inherited, etc.)

When did you start your collection? (Childhood, adulthood, recently, a specific year or period, etc.)

Where do you find the items for your collection? (Travel, shops, online, gifts, etc.)

Who inspired or influenced you to start your collection? (Family, friends, a famous collector, etc.)

How do you care for and maintain your collection? (Storage conditions, cleaning, handling, repairs, etc.)

Section 2: Sample Answers

I collect coins from around the world. It was my grandfather who inspired me to start this collection. He himself was a passionate numismatist and shared his love for coins with me during my childhood. I usually find new additions for my collection when I travel abroad or purchase some rare piece online. To care for my collection, I store the coins in specially made albums that help prevent damage.

I have a large collection of vinyl records. My fascination with music and sound quality made me a vinyl enthusiast. I started collecting records in my late teens when I received a record player as a gift. Most of my collections came from local thrift stores, record stores, and online shops. I keep the records in a cool, dry place and clean them regularly to maintain their quality.

Iâ€™m an ardent postcard collector, something I started as a child out of sheer curiosity for different places in the world. My collection gradually grew as my friends and family learned about it and started sending postcards to me from their travels. I also buy vintage postcards from online auctions. Each postcard is stored in acid-free sleeves to protect them from discoloration and deterioration.

topics: Do you think anyone in your family has the same talent?
solutions:
WH-Questions and Suggestions

Who in your family practices the same hobby or talent as you do?

When did you first notice a family member showcasing this talent?

What similarity can you find in terms of talents or abilities between you and any family member?

Where do these talents tend to be utilized within your family?

How does having a shared talent impact your relationship with that family member?

Suggestions: similarities, hobbies, artistic inclinations, musical aptitude, athletics, intellectual pursuits, cooking abilities, storytelling talents, dancing.

Examples

In my family, my sister and I share a passion for painting. I first noticed this when we both entered and won a local art competition in our early teens. We often engage in friendly competitions and this shared talent has only brought us closer.

My cousin and I have a knack for playing the guitar. We started playing around the same age and often perform at family gatherings. It's an interest that we've developed separately but it's amazing how it brings us together during family events.

One of my aunts and I share a talent for storytelling. A love for literature runs deep in our family and I remember, as a child, she would tell me the most fascinating stories. Now, I enjoy writing and telling my own stories, a talent I believe I got from her.

topics: Do you think your talent can be useful for your future work? Why?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-Questions and Suggestions in Phrases and Words

What talent do you possess?

Detailing your unique talent or multiple talents, indicating the level of proficiency.

Why is your talent valuable?

Highlighting the reasons why your talent can be considered as an asset or an advantage.

How can your talent contribute to your future work?

Discussing possible real-world applications of your talent in different work scenarios and industries.

Which industries or roles may benefit from your talent?

Considering possible careers or industries that would give natural advantage to your talents.

When have you utilized your talent?

Providing examples of situations when your talent has been beneficial and relevant.

Section 2: Sample Answers

Example 1:

I possess a talent for problem-solving and critical thinking. These abilities have always been useful, especially during challenging situations when most people tend to buckle under pressure. I am certain that this talent will come in handy in my future work as a software engineer where it is crucial to solve complex coding problems efficiently. It's not only beneficial in the tech industry but it also applies to numerous fields that require analytical thinking.

Example 2:

My talent lies in interpersonal communication. I find it easy to build rapport with individuals from all walks of life and this ability to connect can go a long way in any work environment. From team collaborations to customer interactions, effective communication is always a necessity. This talent can be particularly beneficial in roles that involve customer service, sales, and management.

Example 3:

I have a knack for creativity, particularly when it comes to design and aesthetics. This talent adds value to my career as a concept artist, where coming up with unique and appealing designs is the norm. This talent is not limited to the field of arts and design but can also be extended to advertising, marketing, and any industry that values innovation and originality.

topics: Was it mastered recently or when you were young?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and Suggestions

WH-questions:

1. When did you master the skill?

2. Were you young or older when you mastered it?

3. What stage in your life were you at when you mastered this skill?

Suggestions:

1. Period in life such as childhood, teenage years, adulthood.

2. The age or specific year when the skill was mastered.

3. Events that occurred around the time you mastered the skill.

Section 2: Examples

Example 1: I mastered the skill of playing the piano when I was quite young. It was around the time I was beginning high school, at about fourteen years old. Music had always fascinated me, and it was then that I had the time and discipline to truly dive into learning.

Example 2: I acquired the ability to speak French fluently much later in my life. In fact, I was already in my early thirties when I moved to France for work. Living in the country and being surrounded by native speakers expedited my mastery of the language.

Example 3: The programming skills that I now possess were not mastered until recently. With the advancement of technology, I realized that learning this skill was quite essential. Hence, to stay on par with the latest trends, I decided to master programming when I was in my late twenties.

topics: Do you have a talent or something you are good at?
solutions:
Talent or Skill

WH-Questions and Suggestions:

What specific talent or skill do you have?

Suggestions: Mention a specific talent or skill like musical instrument, sports, computer programming, etc.

When did you discover this talent or start developing this skill?

Suggestions: Childhood, during school years, recent years, etc.

Where do you usually practice this skill or show this talent?

Suggestions: At home, in a club, in a studio, in the community, etc.

Why do you enjoy this skill or talent?

Suggestions: Provides relaxation, gives a sense of achievement, helps in career, challenges you, etc.

How have you improved or hope to further enhance this talent?

Suggestions: By taking classes, self-learning, getting a mentor, regular practice, etc.

Examples:

Example 1: I am genuinely good at playing the guitar. I discovered this talent when I was in high school and I joined a music club. We performed in various school events and that's where I practice this skill most of the time. I enjoy it because it soothes me and helps me to express my emotions. Over the years, I have improved my guitar skills by watching online tutorials, and I plan to take advanced classes to deepen my skills.

Example 2: I am a talented artist, particularly in the realm of digital art. I discovered this talent during my childhood, but really began honing the skill in college. I practice at home and occasionally do pieces for friends and community events. The process of bringing an image to life truly thrills me. In order to improve, I attend workshops and webinars to learn new techniques and stay updated on digital art trends.

Example 3: I have a knack for programming. I developed this skill during my university years while studying Computer Science. I usually practice and apply my skills at work, where I'm a software developer. I enjoy the challenges it brings and the satisfaction I get when a code runs successfully. To improve, I continue studying and experimenting with different programming languages, and I often participate in coding challenges online.

topics: Do you think it is important to wear a watch? Why?
solutions:
Section 1: WH-questions and Suggestions

What functionality does a watch serve beyond telling time?

(Suggestions: fashion accessory, symbol of status, practical tool)

Why do some people prefer to wear a watch even with a smartphone in hand?

(Suggestions: convenience, ease of access, habit, style)

How does wearing a watch influence one's perception of time or punctuality?

(Suggestions: time awareness, time management, discipline)
Section 2: Examples

A watch serves more than just the functional purpose of time-telling; it is often seen as a fashion accessory. Certain watch brands are seen as symbols of status or wealth, and many people wear them as an extension of their personal style.

While smartphones have largely replaced the necessity for watches, many individuals still prefer to wear one out of habit or convenience. This is often the case in situations where checking a phone could be seen as rude or unprofessional, like during meetings or social gatherings. For others, it's simply a matter of style â€“ a well-chosen watch can complement an outfit or make a fashion statement.

Wearing a watch can definitely have an impact on one's perception of time and punctuality. A quick glance at your wrist can remind you of appointments or deadlines, which can lead to better time management and a more disciplined lifestyle.

topics: Why do some people wear expensive watches?
solutions:
WH-questions and Suggestions

Why do some people choose to wear expensive watches? (Status symbol, show of wealth, appreciation for craftmanship)

What are the feelings they get from wearing an expensive watch? (Confidence, pride, satisfaction)

Who are the typical purchasers of expensive watches? (Professionals, watch collectors, wealthy individuals)

When do these people typically start buying expensive watches? (After reaching certain career or wealth milestones)

Where do these people usually shop for their expensive watches? (Luxury boutiques, online retailers, auctions)

Examples of Answering the Question

Some people choose to wear expensive watches as a status symbol or a demonstration of their wealth. These individuals may have attained a certain level of financial success and view the purchase and display of a high-end watch as a way to showcase this achievement. They may take pride in owning a piece of luxury, and it provides them with a feeling of confidence and accomplishment.

Others buy and wear expensive watches out of a deep appreciation for the craftsmanship and tradition that go into creating these intricate pieces of art. They are typically connoisseurs or collectors, who understand the mechanisms behind each handcrafted timepiece and value the artistry and dedication that goes into their creation. For them, the watch is more than a time-keeping device; it's a testament to human ingenuity and skill.

Expensive watches are often found on the wrists of successful professionals, especially in industries where image and first impressions matter. A luxury timepiece can project an image of success, detail-orientation, and professionalism, helping them establish their presence and credibility.
